title: Canada to Recognize Palestinian State, Sets Conditions
snippets: Mark Carney says the move depends on Palestinian democratic reforms and elections without Hamas.
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has announced that the UK will recognise a Palestinian state in September unless Israel meets certain conditions.
The Canadian PM says Hamas cannot play a role in the future of Palestine or take part in possible 2026 elections.
Canadian PM Mark Carney has justified the move saying that it was necessary to preserve hopes of a two-state solution to the Israel-Palestinian conflict. DW has more.

Follow today’s news live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or
In the past week alone, three new countries have said they are ready to bestow recognition on a Palestinian state.
Canada joins France and Britain in taking similar steps, after months of increasing criticism of Israel by Prime Minister Mark Carney.
Plus, the Booker Prize nominees
The announcements reflect deep frustrations with Israel’s conduct in Gaza and in the occupied West Bank, experts say.
Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada plans to recognize a Palestinian state at the United Nations summit in September, following France while setting up a clash with the US and Israel.
titles: Canada follows France and UK with plan to recognise Palestinian state
What does recognising a Palestinian state mean?
Canada will recognise Palestinian state at UN General Assembly: Carney

Politics live: Canada to recognise Palestinian state but Chalmers declines to say when Australia will follow suit
What Countries Recognize a Palestinian State: A Map
Canada to Recognize Palestinian State at the U.N. General Assembly
Wednesday Briefing: U.K. May Recognize a Palestinian State
What Would Recognizing a Palestinian State Mean?
Canada Plans to Recognize Palestinian State, Joining France, UK
summary: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada announced plans to recognize a Palestinian state at the United Nations summit in September, contingent on Palestinian democratic reforms and excluding Hamas from future elections. This move aligns Canada with France and the UK, which have also expressed intentions to recognize Palestine if Israel does not meet certain conditions. The decision aims to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution to the Israel-Palestinian conflict, amidst widespread criticism of Israel's actions in Gaza and the West Bank. This stance sets up potential disagreements with t
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides comprehensive information about a significant international policy decision. It outlines the conditions set by Canada, the potential implications for the Israel-Palestinian conflict, and the broader international context. It helps readers understand the complexities of the situation and the potential progress towards a solution.

title: Federal Reserve Keeps Rates Steady Amid Dissent and Tariff Concerns

summary: The Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged, a decision that saw dissent from two of its governors, both appointed by President Trump. This marks the first time since 1993 that two out of the seven board members have dissented. The debate continues over how tariffs might impact the U.S. economy, with some support growing for a rate cut.
constructiveness_reason: The story is constructive as it provides useful information about the Federal Reserve's decision and the internal dissent. It also highlights the ongoing debate about the impact of tariffs on the U.S. economy, increasing awareness about the complexities of economic policy.

titles: Flight disruption after major UK air traffic outage

summary: A technical issue at Nats, the UK's air traffic control, caused a 20-minute system malfunction leading to over 150 flights being canceled and significant delays across British airports. The problem was resolved, and flight departures resumed, but it resulted in a massive backlog and public frustration. This incident marks the second major disruption in two years, prompting calls for the resignation of the head of Nats. Affected passengers are entitled to care and assistance during their wait.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about a significant disruption to air travel, but it lacks depth in terms of understanding the underlying issues that led to the glitch. It does, however, inform readers about their rights and entitlements in such situations, which is useful.

title: NASA-ISRO NISAR Satellite Launched to Map Earth in 3D
snippets: The "first of its kind" satellite will map the Earth's surface in incredible detail. Mission officials say it will help us better understand areas at risk of earthquakes.

Carrying an advanced radar system that will produce a dynamic, three-dimensional view of Earth in unprecedented detail, the NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar) satellite has launched from Satish Dhawan Space Center in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh, India.

Editor’s Note: This release was edited on July 30, 2025, to correct the mission launch time in the IST time zone. Carrying an advanced radar system that will produce a dynamic, three-dimensional view of Earth in unprecedented detail, the NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar) satellite has
titles: US, India launch 'first-of-its-kind' satellite to track Earth's surface
NASA-ISRO satellite lifts off to track Earth's changing surfaces
NASA-ISRO Satellite Lifts Off to Track Earth’s Changing Surfaces
summary: The NISAR satellite, a collaboration between NASA and ISRO, was launched from Satish Dhawan Space Center in India. It is equipped with an advanced radar system to map the Earth's surface in unparalleled three-dimensional detail. This "first of its kind" satellite aims to improve our understanding of areas prone to earthquakes. The mission's significance lies in its potential to offer dynamic, detailed insights into the Earth's geological features.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it reports on a technological innovation that can contribute to our understanding of Earth's geological features, particularly areas prone to earthquakes. It provides actionable insights and increases awareness about the potential applications of satellite technology.

title: Trump Criticizes India's Trade, Imposes 25% Tariff on Goods
snippets: President Trump said he would pose an additional penalty on India for its trade relations with Russia, which Trump is trying to pressure over its war with Ukraine.
This deal would mean the duties will be lowered from the 25% that Trump had threatened in his "tariff letter" to Seoul earlier this month.

This move highlights tensions between the US and India regarding trade imbalances and India's energy and arms dealings with Russia.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the ongoing trade tensions between the U.S. and India. However, it lacks depth in terms of exploring the potential impacts of these tariffs, and it doesn't report on any attempts to solve these trade issues.

snippets: Arenas is accused of renting out his mansion for an illegal gambling business

title: Magnet Experiments Shed Light on Gradual Climate System Collapses
snippets: Some of Earth's largest climate systems may collapse not with a bang, but with a whimper. Surprisingly, experiments with magnets are helping us understand how.

This research offers a new perspective on understanding the dynamics of climate change and the potential slow shifts in significant environmental systems.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it offers a deeper understanding of climate change dynamics. It highlights the progress in research and provides useful insights into potential slow shifts in significant environmental systems.

title: Gulf of Maine Seawater Acidity Stable, Benefiting Shellfish Fisheries
snippets: The Gulf of Maine—home to commercial fisheries for oysters, clams and mussels—has unexpectedly avoided an increase in seawater acidity, helping to preserve the health of its fisheries.
titles: Gulf of Maine sees rising pH, defying expectations of increasing ocean acidity
summary: The Gulf of Maine, a vital area for oyster, clam, and mussel fisheries, has not experienced a rise in seawater acidity as anticipated. This unexpected development has been beneficial in maintaining the health of the fisheries in the region.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on a positive development in the environment, specifically in the context of climate change and its impact on fisheries. It provides useful information for those involved in or interested in fisheries and marine conservation.

title: Archaeologists Study 2,000-Year-Old Siberian Mummy Tattoos with Digital Imaging
snippets: An international team of archaeologists has used high-resolution digital imaging techniques to examine tattoos on a more than 2,000-year-old ice mummy from the Pazyryk culture of Siberia, shedding light on individual craftsmanship in prehistoric Siberian tattooing for the first time.
titles: Modern tattooers meet their ancient match with the ice mummies of Siberia
summary: An international team of archaeologists has utilized high-resolution digital imaging to study tattoos on a Siberian ice mummy over 2,000 years old, from the Pazyryk culture. This research marks the first time individual craftsmanship in prehistoric Siberian tattooing has been examined in detail, offering new insights into ancient practices.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into ancient practices and the progress in archaeological research. However, it might not directly contribute to the reader's decision-making or sense of agency, hence the score is slightly lower.

title: Harvard Researchers Condense Quantum Computer onto Single Chip

title: Moonquakes, Not Meteor Impacts, Alter Apollo 17 Site, Study Finds
snippets: A new paper reveals that ground acceleration from moonquakes, rather than meteor impacts, was responsible for shifting lunar landscapes at the moon's Taurus-Littrow valley, where Apollo 17 astronauts landed in 1972. The study also pinpointed a possible cause for those surface changes and assessed da
titles: Seismic activity on the moon could pose risk to long-term lunar infrastructure
summary: A recent study has discovered that the changes in the lunar landscape at the Taurus-Littrow valley, the landing site of Apollo 17 in 1972, were primarily caused by moonquakes, not meteor impacts as previously thought. The research further suggests a potential cause for these surface alterations, providing new insights into lunar seismic activity.
constructiveness_reason: The story is informative and provides a deeper understanding of lunar seismic activity, which could be useful for space research and exploration. However, it doesn't highlight any specific solutions or improvements, hence the score is slightly less than maximum.
